title: 'Odd taste of wine' was mum's first indicator she was having a heart attack
text:

The first sign of a heart attack for Louise McGill was a funny tasting wine - now she wants to help other women to recognise early symptoms of what can be a fatal condition.

At the time, Louise , from Waterhouses, in Staffordshire, didn’t think much of the unusual flavour of wine she had enjoyed after a family day out.

But later that night, Louise, who was 45 at the time, awoke in the night with chest pains and was blue-lighted to hospital.

"The first sign that something wasn’t right was when I had a glass of wine and it tasted really funny," she said.

"My husband tried some too and said it was fine, so I didn’t think much of it.

“That night, I woke up just after midnight with excruciating pain and pressure in my chest.

"At first I thought it might be indigestion but I quickly realised that something wasn’t right and my husband called an ambulance.

"When the paramedics arrived they said they thought I was having a heart attack. I looked at my husband and just started sobbing.

"I guess I was in shock and my first thought was that I was going to die.”

Louise had a stent fitted into her left coronary artery at the Freeman Hospital in Newcastle, Chronicle Live reports.

She added: “As soon as the stent was put in place I immediately began to feel better. I couldn’t believe it was that quick. The surgeon said there is a second blockage in my other artery, but it’s not big enough to need a stent.”

Now the mum of twin daughters is campaigning for women to look after their heart health from a young age - as she worries too often heart attacks are assumed to impact only men.

The British Heart Foundation has launched a new briefing, revealing the inequalities in awareness, diagnosis and treatment of heart attacks killing women in the UK.

In the North East alone, around 1,600 women are admitted to hospital following a heart attack each year, the BHF says.

The charity estimates that around 17,000 women in the North East, like Louise, have survived a heart attack.

The BHF says its new research shows women often delay seeking medical help by more than two hours, reducing their chance of survival.

Speaking about the brewing symptoms, Louise, said: “Looking back at the week before I was really tired and working long hours and juggling life with the kids.

"Two nights after I got back from work I literally fell asleep on the sofa, which was really unusual for me. I thought I’d just hit a wall because of being a busy working mum – which I realise now is a typical female response.

"I had extreme tiredness before mine, but thought it was just because I was busy.”

Now Louise is more conscious of how and what she eats. She has also been proactive in creating a healthier work-life balance by not overworking or committing to long hours.

In a bid to educate her daughters, Louise confides in them about the reason they are going for a walk or doing sport.

Worryingly, according to the BHF briefing, more than 8,200 women in England and Wales alone died over a 10-year period because they did not receive equal treatment to men.

But despite these stark figures, the condition is more treatable than it has ever been.

Dr Sonya Babu-Narayan, Consultant Cardiologist and Associate Medical Director of the British Heart Foundation, said: “Women are dying needlessly because heart attacks are often seen as a man’s disease, and women simply don’t receive the same standard of treatment as men.

"The studies detailed in this briefing have revealed inequalities at every stage of a woman’s medical journey, and though complex to dissect, they add up to a societal failure to provide fair care for women. Together, we must change this."

Dr Babu-Narayan added one of the first steps in closing the gender gap is to raise national awareness of such inequalities and to tackle public perception of women and heart attacks.
description: Louise McGill,  hopes to inform other women of heart attack symptoms as British Heart Foundation reveals women are dying needlessly because attacks are seen as a man’s disease
